Kernel/sources/stack/stack.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 #include <stack/stack.h>
00002 #include <mm/virt_mm.h>
00003 #include <debug/debug.h>
00004 #include <types/memory.h>
00005 #include <panic/panic.h>
00006 
00007 
00008 //Function: moveStack
00009 //Arguments: new start, size, initial stack pointer
00010 //Returns: the location of the new stack (The value passed in new_start) if succesful, null otherwise
00011 //NOTE: A stack unwinds downards, so the mapping = new_start to new_start - size
00012 
00013 stack_t moveStack(MEM_LOC new_start, size_t size, MEM_LOC initial_esp) 
00014 {
00015 
00016         MEM_LOC iter = 0; //for iterator
00017 
00018 
00019         MEM_LOC end = new_start - size; //The stack expands downwards.
00020 
00021         //This for loop maps new_start to new_start - size with physical memory
00022         for (iter = new_start; iter >= end; iter -= PAGE_SIZE) 
00023         {
00024                 MEM_LOC frame = allocateFrame(); //Allocate the frame
00025 
00026                 map(iter, (POINTER) frame, PAGE_PRESENT | PAGE_WRITE | PAGE_USER); //Map it to the virtual address
00027         }
00028 
00029         stack_t old_stack_pointer = 0; 
00030         asm volatile("mov %%esp, %0" : "=r" (old_stack_pointer)); //The old stack & base pointers = the esp & ebp registers respectivally
00031 
00032         stack_t old_base_pointer = 0;
00033         asm volatile("mov %%ebp, %0" : "=r" (old_base_pointer)); 
00034 
00035         //Use a big int because the stack may be moving backwards in memory (Needs to be possible positive or negative)
00036         int64 offset = ((size_t)new_start) - initial_esp;
00037 
00038         //Calculate the new stack & base pointers by adding the offset between the stack locations
00039         stack_t new_stack_pointer = (stack_t) (((size_t)old_stack_pointer) + offset);
00040         stack_t new_base_pointer  = (stack_t) (((size_t)old_base_pointer ) + offset);
00041 
00042         //Copy over the new stack - copy size initial_esp - esp to new_stack_pointer
00043         //This copies the size between the current stack pointer and the initial stack start to the new stack
00044         memcpy((void*)new_stack_pointer, (void*)old_stack_pointer, initial_esp -  ((size_t)old_stack_pointer));
00045         
00046         size_t i = 0;
00047 
00048         for(i = (size_t) new_start; i > (size_t) new_start-size; i -= sizeof(uint32))
00049         {
00050            //Clarification on this ickle bit. tmp = *i (The actual value of memory at location i) 
00051            size_t tmp = *(size_t*)i;
00052 
00053            // If the value of tmp is inside the range of the old stack, assume it is a base pointer
00054            // and remap it. This will unfortunately remap ANY value in this range, whether they are
00055            // base pointers or not.
00056            if ((((size_t)old_stack_pointer) < tmp) && (tmp < initial_esp))
00057            {
00058              tmp = tmp + offset;
00059              size_t *tmp2 = (size_t*)i;
00060              *tmp2 = tmp;
00061            }
00062         }
00063 
00064         //Set the ESP and EBP to the new stack.
00065         asm volatile("mov %0, %%esp" : : "r" (new_stack_pointer));
00066         asm volatile("mov %0, %%ebp" : : "r" (new_base_pointer));
00067 
00068         return new_start;
00069 }
